name: Eggplant Salad
description: Ruth Reichl serves this in a bowl for people to fork onto crackers while having a glass of wine or a cocktail. It also works well alongside grilled meat or just over rice for a little lunch. “What I love most about cooking with eggplant,” she writes in "My Kitchen Year: 136 Recipes That Saved My Life," the book in which this recipe appeared, “is their complete docility: No other vegetable is so content to abandon itself to your will.”
recipeCategory: snack, dips and spreads, finger foods
recipeIngredient: 1 1/2 pounds long, thin Asian or baby eggplants

recipeInstructions.text: Prick the eggplants all over with a fork and singe them over the burner of a gas stove, turning constantly, for about 10 minutes until the skin is black and blistered. Allow to cool.
Carefully peel the eggplant skin. (This can be fussy, but you want to get all the skin off.) Pull the eggplant into strips and lay them in a shallow bowl.

Mix the fish sauce with the lime juice, the sugar and a couple of tablespoons of water. Add the minced garlic and chile flakes. Pour over the eggplant and marinate in the refrigerator for a few hours. When ready to serve, garnish with a few leaves of chopped cilantro or mint.
